channel.title: Posts on CogSci to DatSci
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on CogSci to DatSci

item.title: Converting from wide to long format & ANOVA in R
item.description: Introduction In this post, I will discuss about how to convert data from wide format to long format; how to create a 2D figure with information from 3 variables; and how to conduct ANOVA in 3 different ways. The data in today’s example was collected by our lab (led by Dr. Paul Minda) for the purpose of predicting category-learning on two types of categories (i.e.,RD: Rule-defined, and II: Information Integration). Columns from B to AY are all predictive variables.

item.title: A Plain Markdown Post
item.description: This is a post written in plain Markdown (*.md) instead of R Markdown (*.Rmd). The major differences are: You cannot run any R code in a plain Markdown document, whereas in an R Markdown document, you can embed R code chunks (```{r}); A plain Markdown post is rendered through Blackfriday, and an R Markdown document is compiled by rmarkdown and Pandoc. There are many differences in syntax between Blackfriday’s Markdown and Pandoc’s Markdown.

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.

item.title: Exploratory Factor Analysis using R
item.description: Introduction In this post I will be using the 20-item CESD questionnaire as an example to conduct an exploratory factor analysis. The 20 items are shown in the figure below. Item 4, 8, 12, 16 are reverse-coded. Preparation Install Packages #install.packages("Hmisc") #install.packages('corrplot') #install.packages('psych') #install.packages('nFactors') #install.packages('GPArotation') #install.packages('sem') Load libraries library(knitr) library(Hmisc) library(corrplot) library(psych) library(GPArotation) library(rmarkdown) library(sem) Data Manipulation Subsetting data<-read.csv('CESD.csv') # exclude variables cesdx4,cesdx8,cesdx12, cesdx16 myvars <- names(data) %in% c("cesdx4", "cesdx8", "cesdx12", "cesdx16","gender") data <- data[!

item.title: Using VLookup to match grades for M/C exams
item.description: Introduction As graduate Teaching Assitants, we are often assigned mundane tasks which require little to no intelletual involvement, and would be rather time consuming if no automatic method was applied. One of the tasks that is often assigned to us is posting grades for courses whose exam format is Multiple Choices. The way you want to avoid We would start with a .dat file containing the grades of the students that have taken part in the exam, along with their student numbers (but not their names).
